Acrodermatitis enteropathica-like eruption (AELE) is a category of adenoiditis (exogenous acute dermatitis of the skin) often caused by superinfection of atopic dermatitis. The presentation is characterized by prominent erythematous, scaly plaques that are highly irritable and pruritic.

In this patient, atopic dermatitis has been present since birth and has been the child’s most dominant skin issue. Atopy is associated with a range of skin abnormalities, including crusted lesions, crust burden, and inflammation. In addition, atopic dermatitis is associated with systemic symptoms such as fever, urticarial rash, and failure to thrive.

This case involves the presentation of atopic dermatitis with systemic disease. Owing to the failure to thrive, this patient has been advised to switch to formula feeding. This condition is usually related to excess atopic reactions and is thus highly correlated with a high dietary cost and potential zinc deficiency.

This patient has been breastfed since birth, and switched to formula 2 months ago. He develops signs and symptoms of atopic dermatitis. He has recurrent episodes of atopic dermatitis, itching, and wheezing, associated with multi-dermal lesions, hyperkeratosis, and hyphronta. His recurrent atopic dermatitis is associated with failure to thrive and atopic urticarial skin lesions periorbital and perianal. His recurrent atopic dermatitis is associated with an increased frequency of eosinophilia and IgE (serum (seroparse) and skin tests).

Dermatologist confirmed the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis. Thus, eosinophilia is commonly seen in atopic dermatitis. Eosinophils are granulocytes that differentiate in response to IgE antibodies against high-affinity CD218k and CD79a markers expressed on B and B-cell subsets, responsible for type I hypersensitivity reactions to inhaled and orally-administered allergens. These cells also play a major role in host defense against parasitic infections and damage from certain drugs, parasites, and allergens. In atopic dermatitis, these cells infiltrate the skin and can also deposit them in the bone marrow, causing peripheral eosinophilia.

Ivermectin is implicated in the treatment of atopic dermatitis. With current evidence of zinc deficiency, this patient should be treated for zinc supplementation. Interestingly, the patient has been exclusively breastfed, which contains less zinc than cow milk.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica (ADE) is a type of exogenous enteropathogenic infection, commonly seen in young children with atopic eczema, food allergies, or recurrent atopic dermatitis. There are several organisms causing ADE, but most often it is caused by *Staphylococcus aureus* or certain phytaminotic bacteria like *Staphylococcal phytaminides*. Superinfection of ADE usually results in salmon-throat cellulitis or cellulitis of the skin which may follow a deep tissue infection. This can lead to destruction of the necrotic tissue.

Patients with ADE usually present with a painful, erythematous, scaly eruption on the epidermis. This is due to the shedding of the upper epidermal keratin layers, which are very similar to normal skin, but when keratinocytes are dead, exposed basal lamina, and inflammatory cells become easily recognized by bacteria. In addition, AD is often associated with bullous impetigo and margins in the groin area and anus, deep skin infections and destruction of cellular layers in the diaper area, and scaly lesions after trauma such as diaper changes or scratching.

This patient has "thin, oily, red, scaly plaques and erosions around his mouth, anus, eyes, hands, and feet", which are quite typical of ADE. He also develops failure to thrive, which can occur due to superinfection infections, osmotic diarrhea, or secondary bacterial infection following eczema. His poor nutritional status (poor diet, food intolerances, allergy to foods) predisposes to nutritional rickets or malabsorption which are associated with ADE. The lesions in this 7-month-old boy were confirmed to be AD after confirmation of the presence of *Staphylococcus aureus* by gram stain on skin swab.

Staphylococcus aureus is one of the most common pathogens to cause ADE. The *Staph aureus* pathogen injects yolk sac protein (YSP) into the host, along with hyroeclastin, which normally suppresses the inflammatory response against skin pathogens. When an allergic reaction occurs due to ingestion or skin exposure of *Staph aureus* toxins, these toxins can trigger an inflammatory response and clinical and laboratory signs of atopic dermatitis along with AD. The presence of *Staph aureus* can be confirmed via demonstration of gram (-) negative bacilli in skin smears taken from the lesions.

This patient has been exclusively breastfed, therefore he has been exposed to *Streptococcus pyogenes* (the gram (-) bacillus) in his skin via skin-to-skin contact at birth and frequently during diaper changes. Frequent skin-to-skin contact is often accompanied by transfer of bacteria to the rectal area and subsequent ingestion.

Acute adenoiditis is a common childhood condition caused by cold virus causing adenioitis in children 2-3 years of age. This condition is characterized by adenoidomeanitis, lymphangitis, and conjunctivitis. It usually appears between the ages of 2 to 5 years. The condition is most commonly due to *Haemophilus influenzae* type b (Hib). While *Haemophilus influenzae* and others can also cause acute adenoiditis, Hib is the most common causative organism. The presence of capsular *Haemophilus seroparae* can be identified in blood cultures and is usually positive in children 2-5 years of age.

Haemophilia avicularis-like disease (HAIC) is a rare autoimmune disease that primarily affects adolescents and young adults. It may follow myeloid malignancies or autoimmune diseases. Ivermectin is indicated in this condition due to its efficacy against *Necroidium* (a descended cell from skin and mucosal surfaces) infection in the urinary bladder, inflammation of the urinary bladder, and prostatitis. Ivermectin has a high level of effect on vipern, and for this reason is one of the treatment options for HAIC.

Hyperigliosuria refers to an accumulation of glycogen (form of glucose) in blood and the eye. Glycogen is a storage form of glucose that can be stored as a gel-like substance in the liver, muscle, and fat. Elevated levels of glycogen in blood and eye indicate a problem where excess amounts of glycogen are being converted back to glucose (glycogenesis) and causing problems.

Aurodermatas is an exogenous bacterial infection of the skin by Staphylococcus epidermidis, a commensal skin bacteria that normally inhabit the skin and hair follicles in the mouth, nasal passages, and other areas of the skin. Aurodermatas is often associated with atopic dermatitis and is considered to be one of the most common bacterial causes of cutaneous infections in young children. A *Staphylococcus epidermidis* infection, also known as diaper rash, commonly affects the diaper area in young children after diaper changes due to fecal bacteria contaminant on the diaper surface.

Acute atopic dermatitis-like eruption (AELE) includes the presentation of a transient pustular erythema on the upper trunk, particularly on the face and neck, commonly in babies who are not immunized to *Staphylococcus epidermidis*. It is caused by bacterial infection with *Staphylococcus epidermidis*. In its severe form, it may be complicated by cellulitis and postinvasive candidiasis. Most cases can be treated with a single dose of impropinazole, erythromycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (STP).

Immunodeficiency is a condition in which the immune system of the host is deficient and unable to mount an appropriate response to pathogenic agents. It can cause a wide variety of diseases, including autoimmune diseases, opportunistic infections, and failure to thrive.

Nail dystrophy is a degenerative condition affecting the nails in which keratinocytes (cells that produce nails) are destroyed, resulting in abnormal, shortened nails that are brittle and discolored. Associated conditions include osteogenesis imperfecta, calcific tendon disease (Caffrodys), and post metastatic consequences of lymphoma. Nail dystrophy may result from nutritional deficiencies.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica-like eruption (AELE) is a rare childhood skin disease, most commonly occurring in children who are heterozygous for Familial Autoimmune Eczema (FALS). It is characterized by painful papular eruptions on the chest and abdomen that are rich in firm, red, crust-like lesions with burrows. The lesions are classically grouped into three types: papulosquamous, pustular, and serpiginiform. Papulosquamous lesions typically appear on the chest and are dotted with furrows and nodules while psutular lesions are grouped in pairs and usually occur on the shins and buttocks. Serpiginiform lesions are discrete papules covered with a parchment-red color and found scaly and rough. These lesions are associated with a childhood genetic disease called FALS. This resembles atopic dermatitis, but it is different from atopic dermatitis in several aspects. Unlike AD, the incubation period is longer, and the eruption is not preceded by pruritus. Also, instead of pruritus, AELE patients usually experience intense itching at the site of the dermatitis. The recurrent and severe itching is the distinguishing hallmark of AELE. Unlike atopic dermatitis, AELE is not associated with any specific food allergies. They often present as typical childhood edema with peeling and crusting similar to varicella. The differential diagnosis with other skin conditions commonly includes contact dermatitis, atopic dermatitis, and seborrheoid dermatitis. The diagnosis is made based on history and examination, though skin scrapings or blood cultures may be useful in some cases. The treatment is mainly oral antimicrobials with broad spectra antibiotics such as erythromycin, azithromycin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).

Agranulocytopenia is characterized by decreased number of blood platelets in the circulation. Platelets are important components of blood that are involved in the removal of blood from the body as well as essential in the healing of wounds. Platelets are produced in bone marrow (the “granulosa reticularis”). Platelet count is maintained within a narrow range with the approximate range of 100,000 to 1,500,000 capillaries and platelets per million cubic centimeters of body weight.

This patient has atopic dermatitis. This is a skin disorder characterized by excessive skin moisture, a strong tendency to itch, and a´painful, red, flaky, or fissured skin with hyperkeratosis involving keratinocytes on the deeper layers of the skin. The primary manifestation of atopic dermatitis is in young children. A common association of atopic dermatitis in this age group is recurrent atopic wheezing. This child has had atopic episodes for several years and is well aware of the association. The recurrent episodes were associated with minimal prompt reactions (such as antihistamines) to any allergen and normally resolves spontaneously after a few hours. Over time, the behavior changes and less severe reactions occur, and the patient complains less frequently but still does not have complete resolution of symptoms. The association with atopic dermatitis is complicated by a failure to thrive and, in this case, poor nutritional status (both insufficient caloric intake and low levels of zinc) for this age group. Rapid weight loss in this age group can also lead to skin problems. This child has been exclusively breastfed, and the introduction of formula feeding within 2 months of birth is a critical change that may have led to atopic episodes. The failure to thrive is compounded by poor nutritional status. The patient used a broad spectrum of antibiotics for 10 weeks before his symptoms began.

This child grazing formula since breastfeeding was a major risk factor for atopic dermatitis in this age group. Breastfeeding provides essential nutrients to the baby including immunoglobulins and growth factors that protect against atopic conditions. When a breastfed infant is adopted or starts eating formula, he/she no longer receives these essential nutrients. In this case the formula was formulated during the outbreak of an enterotoxic enteritis in Germany (Rotavirus). This condition was seen almost universally with symptoms of vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, wasting, and diarrheal sickness primarily in children who are already chronically ill and frequently ill. The persistent use of antibiotics and parenteral nutrition eventually led to the development of atopic dermatitis. The wide range of bacterial and viral pathogens acquired while being exposed to the outside may lead to dysbiosis of the skin.

Being a breastfed baby, this child was exposed early on to *Staphylococcus epidermidis* which normally inhabit the nimbus layer of skin and facial hair follicles as well as the nasal passages and colon. This bacteria can cause endotractocutaneous spastic parainfectious dermatitis (AAPD), which is characterized by irritable, edematous, edematous skin with papules, erythema, and nodules that protect against scratching. AAPD is typically associated with a lack of rhizomaligens (specifically, defensins, cathelicycins, and serines) essential for recognition by neutrophils. This condition is often associated with food allergies and eczema. It is diagnosed by biopsy of the dermis showing the presence of microverficrous granules containing immature neutrophils and abundant keratinocytes in the dermis. The lesions are pigmented because the bacteria reside in the stratum corneum.

Cottonwood patchy stomatosis is a common childhood disease that presents with painful red papules on the trunk and buttocks and often accompanied by fever, malaise, and irritability. The lesions are grouped into patches of papules or papulovesicles and may vary in size from small pea to tennis-ball size. They are often bilateral, are distributed especially on the torso and buttocks, and their appearance changes over time. The lesions in cottonwood patchy stomatosis are due to bacterial endophytic growth over the denser upper layers of skin. The lesions are often associated with food allergies and immersion of the epidermis in prebiotic substances.

This case exhibits the typical micro-pustular eruption of atopic dermatitis. This could be either a result of allergic bronchial asthma, food allergy, pregnancy, or chronic immune mediated inflammation of the skin. Currently, it is not clear to what extent it is associated with a particular idiotype of atopic dermatitis. Nail dystrophy is a common finding in atopic dermatitis presenting as nonspecific changes in the nail beds. A fibroblastic smear shows iron deposition being highlighted with iron peroxidase (His1) which can be differentiated from iron stores by their staining affinity for Prussian blue.

Dermatologic findings mimicking atopic dermatitis include pruritus, eczema, and typically the manifestation of the condition is in the form of serpiginiform erythematous plaques on the arms and upper trunk. Pigmented atopic dermatitis (PARD) is defined as a subgroup of atopic dermatitis with a relatively benign course and poor response to therapy, which is heavily influenced by genetic factors. Typically, atopic dermatitis presents an inflammatory process in the skin inducing an immune response. This skin condition is associated with increased IgE levels and IgE-Feta is predominately present. Remarkably, the disease typically progresses with age, and patients may complain of prodromal non-pruritic eruptions and general malaise and may also complain of sleep problems. A well-defined association of atopic dermatitis and nail disease has been described where the presence of commensal bacteria such as *Staphylococcus aureus* or *Staphylococcal phytaminides*, especially *Staphylococcus epidermidis*, leads to abnormal nail structure. ***Staphylococcus aureus* causes this condition by adhering to the upper epidermal layer, often in areas of relatively poor keratinocyte turnover which are literally blown off during scratching. This process leads to an increased number of free-lying keratinocytes that become a feeding source for the bacteria. This then leads to a condition that is not a variant of atopic dermatitis."

The correct answer is C. This identifies the likely cause of the atopic dermatitis. AAD features the same skin lesions as atopic dermatitis. The difference between atopic dermatitis and PARD is their association with other skin conditions. In cases of PARD, the skin lesions are usually milder and less likely to cover large areas of the body. The distinguishing features of PARD include the absence of intense pruritus. Patients may experience some itching but usually it is masked by itching associated with other skin lesions such as atopic bullous impetigo, oral ulcers, and rhizoonychitis. In this patient streaks of periodontis-like lesions are found on the vertical zones of the acral web spaces and flexor aspects of the lower extremities. These lesions are similar to atopic dermatitis but are usually not itchy and are localized to the acral regions. This case is likely to be PARD as this is the most common type of atopic dermatitis in children. This disease is associated with an IgE-mediated response and an impaired blood-cytokine profile mimicking inflammatory processes. The patient has had atopic reactions in the past but rarely had a history of atopic wheezing or fever. He has a strong family history for autoimmune disease including type 1 diabetes mellitus and isolated Ashcraft-Luke syndrome (LAS). The presentation of generalized atopic disease with fever, malaise and crusting is highly suggestive of ADE. This case is likely to be PARD as this is the most common type of atopic dermatitis in children. A subset of PARD is associated with elevated serum cholesterol and blood pressure due to deficiency of serine and altered cytokine production. The lesions are in a distribution pattern similar to atopic dermatitis with a greater prevalence in children. His recurrent atopic dermatitis is associated with failure to thrive, which can occur secondary to an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. His recurrent episodes of atopic dermatitis are associated with IgE antibodies. The oral lesions are classically described as having a typical “punctuate” edematous appearance with scaling and crusting. The differential diagnosis is eczema and interspersed alopecia. The presence of keratitis along with photosensitivity and the patient history of atopic dermatitis and milk allergies definitively suggests atopic dermatitis.

Imprisoned animals are not at adequate risk for this disease because they are breastfed and have not been in close contact with dogs or cats. Methicillin is not indicated in atopic dermatitis as it may worsen existing atopic condition.

ADE or Acrodermatitis Enteropathica-like Eruption is an exogenous enterovirus infection that produces an exogenous enterovaccine that causes an enteropathic dermatitis of the dermis. This includes superinfection of atopic dermatitis and the development of fever due to extraintestinal spread to the bloodstream. Patients usually have atopic wheezing with a polyuria, abdominal pain, anorexia and fever. The lesions are grouped into erythematous macules and papules on the shins, buttocks, and buttocks of the neck and the palms and soles of the feet. The lesions are usually small and are easily overlooked. Delayed treatment of atopic dermatitis and AELE may result in a chronic exacerbation of the disease.

AELE refers to Atypical Epidermolysis, a common childhood disease characterized by acute rashes on the trunk and buttocks, often in the form of small pustules with surrounding erythema and vesicles. Candidal psoriasis is a condition characterized by findings of atopic dermatitis and psoriasis, and is mediated via type I interferon pathway with type I interferon-alpha being the main cytokine. There is an association between atopic dermatitis and nail disease. Nail dystrophy is normally associated with hyperkeratosis which may be associated with atopic dermatitis. Nail hypoprotection is a common feature of atopic dermatitis affecting the levels of keratinocytes. Conditions associated with atopic dermatitis include atopic bullous impetigo, discoid atopic dermatitis, and interdigital alopecia. Nacre dissolution can be seen in atopic dermatitis and can be part of PARD. They are associated with differential diagnosis with atopic dermatitis. The topical treatment with topical corticosteroids is preferred.

Combining the above-mentioned supportive features, we can classify "Acrodermatitis enteropathica-like eruption (AELE)" as the differential diagnosis to exclude from this case.
